title: 113_s643
content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" aims to enhance cost savings. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to include provisions for identifying surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority by agency employees, with referrals to the Chief Financial Officer for further action if deemed necessary. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to allow agency employees to identify surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority, which can be transferred to the general fund of the Treasury for deficit reduction. The agency head can retain up to 10% of the transferred amount for cash awards. The head of each agency can retain up to 10% of transferred funds for cash awards to employees who identify surplus funds. An annual report must be submitted to the Director of the Office of Personnel Management detailing savings achieved through employee disclosures and cash awards given. This information must also be included in each budget request submitted to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management ensures agency compliance with cash award programs and submits annual certifications to Congress. The Comptroller General submits reports on the operation of cost savings and awards programs every three years. The Comptroller General of the United States submits reports to Congress every three years on the operation of cost savings and awards programs, with recommendations for legislative changes. Officers at certain levels are prohibited from receiving cash awards under specific conditions. The Comptroller General of the United States submits reports to Congress every three years on cost savings and awards programs, with recommendations for legislative changes. Certain officers are prohibited from receiving cash awards under specific conditions. Amendments are made to the table of sections for chapter 45 of title 5, United States Code. Prohibition of cash award to certain officers under specific conditions.
